syllabus:
**NEWS MEDIA ENGLISH**

  

**Honors Program, NTNU****, Fall 20****11**

  

  

**Class Time:** Wednesday, 12:10-2:00 p.m. **Office:** 705 Honesty Hall

  

**Classroom:** 701A, Honesty Hall **Office Hours:** By appointment

  

**Instructor:** Chun-yen “Jo” Chen **Email:** jochen@ntnu.edu.tw

  

  

**_Course Objectives_****_._**

  

This course aims to enhance students’ English proficiency through guided reading of various types of news articles. Students will have a chance to familiarize themselves with the style of journalistic writing, build their vocabulary, sharpen their reading comprehension, and keep current with world news. As the class is conducted entirely in English, students will also get a chance to improve their spoken English.

  

  

**_Course Material._**

  

l _English by Newspaper_, by Terry L. Fredrickson and Paul F. Wedel, published by Thomson, 1984. (Available at文鶴書局, 金山南路2段200號3樓. Mention course title and ask for discounts.)

  

l Assigned news articles. Most of these will be handed out in class. Occasionally you may have to download an article from our e-learning platform Moodle: <http://moodle.ntnu.edu.tw/>. Be sure to keep an active email account there.

**_How to Study for This Course._**

  

l Be sure to finish all the assigned reading prior to class meeting.

  

l Study vocabulary actively. This is essential to the advancement of your English proficiency. Make use of the glossary (definition of vocabulary) at the back of the textbook.

  

l After reading a news story, you should learn to summarize it in your own words (this is a skill called “paraphrase”).

  

l Class activities may include the following: \--paraphrasing a news story

  

\--going over difficult words and sentences

  

\--drilling sentence patterns

  

\--discussing the news story

  

  

**_Requirements._**

  

l Conscientious preparation, regular attendance, and active class participation.

  

l Choice between an oral presentation and a reading response. Those who choose to give a presentation should sign up at the beginning of the semester (see class schedule below for weekly topics). Make a ten-minute presentation on the “spotlight news media of the week.” Avoid meandering on the website of the news agency through those “menus.” Alternatively, you may choose to write a 400-word reading response to any assigned news article we read this term. Turn it in any day before the final exam.

  

l Three exams (focus: vocabulary, sentence patterns, and reading comprehension).

  

  

  

**_Grading._**

  

attendance and class participation 30%

  

presentation or reading response 10%

  

exams 60%

  

  

**\*\*\*****CHEATING ON EXAMS WILL NOT BE TOLERATED.**
